TRANSPASS.name: Transit Pass
TRANSPASS.description: Trusty old transit pass. The expiration date is smudged, but I don't recall it being that way.

LIBCARD.name: Library Card
LIBCARD.description: The edges are frayed, like it’s been chewed on. The barcode is faded, but it still seems to work for now.

LETTER.name: Letter
LETTER.description: The words are cut from magazines: 'WE HAVE YOUR DAUGHTER. SHE WAS CHOSEN FOR THIS FATE. GO FOLLOW THE TIDE' ...A haiku? Really?

DAGGER.name: Ritual Dagger
DAGGER.description: The blade is etched with symbols that shift under direct light. The hilt is wrapped in hair too coarse to be my daughter’s.

ROBE.name: Fancy Robes
ROBE.description: The gold embroidery glints like knife-edges in the dark, forming patterns that hurt to focus on. This robe seems fit for a king — or a sacrifice.

ROPE.name: Length of Rope
ROPE.description: The fibers are stained in uneven patches. It smells of salt and wet earth, though it hasn't left the attic in years.

LADDER.name: Metal Stepladder
LADDER.description: The metal is pocked with rust, except for the steps, which are polished smooth from use. The bottom is caked in a dried, flaking residue.

BULLHORN.name: Bullhorn
BULLHORN.description: The megaphone's speaker grille is dented, as if gripped too tightly. When I turn the bullhorn over, a single word is scratched into the plastic: ‘DON’T.’

KEY.name: Steel Key
KEY.description: It’s cold, even in my pocket. The teeth are jagged, like they were filed to fit a lock that shouldn’t exist.

FLYER.name: Recruitment Flyer
FLYER.description: The paper crackles in my hand. An open eye gazes from a circle of waves, printed in deep navy blue. Beneath it, bold words: 'The Tide is rising. Be cleansed. Be claimed.' No contact info. Just coordinates.

DETECTOR.name: Metal Detector
DETECTOR.description: The LCD pulses, even when the device is turned off. The casing is cracked, revealing wires that also seem to pulse faintly, like veins.

GUN.name: Revolver
GUN.description: The grip is sticky. The serial number has been scraped away oddly, as if by metallic fingernails...

APPOINTMENT.description: I booked an appointment to speak with a Detective Rook.

SHACK.description: The cult owns a shack on a private beach north of the pier.

MANSION.description: I know the location of a mansion that belongs to the cult.

CULTISTS.description: I know what these cultists wear. I could sneak in if I could find a robe...

POLICE.description: I have permission to enter the station without an appointment.

TUNNEL.description: I found out tunnels on the mansion grounds lead inside.

COMBO.description: A number sequence I found. 6-20-25. Seems important.

FAMILY.description: My family history may be... darker... than I thought...

ABDUCTOR.description: I have access to video footage showing the cultist taking my daughter.

DOGGO.description: A very friendly doggo met me on the beach today...

FBI.description: I've notified the FBI of the situation in town...

PUBLIC.description: I've stirred up public opinion regarding the cult activity...

EMAIL.description: I know the e-mail address for the detective... Rook@HFPD... simple.

events.home1:
I wake up at home. The silence is first thing that feels wrong. No breakfast sounds. No cartoons. No laughter. Just the groan of the water heater and the hum of the refrigerator.

'Hey, kiddo?'

No answer. Down the hall her door sits open, revealing an unmade bed and an untouched backpack. The house is too still.
events.home2: Inside my house the air tastes stale, thick with absence, like a breath held too long. I tell myself she just forgot to leave a note. I almost believe it. Almost. The house disagrees, its silence screaming what I won't admit: she's been gone longer than I think.
events.dresser1:
On the table I find my trusty transit pass. But why is it on a stack of takeout menus? I don't remember putting it there. I take it, trying not to think too hard about it. Then pause - there's something else.

A letter. Wax-sealed. Torn edges. Words cut from magazines:

'WE HAVE YOUR DAUGHTER.
SHE WAS CHOSEN FOR THIS FATE.
GO FOLLOW THE TIDE.'

It smells like the ocean. And something rotten.
events.hall: The hall closet yields a collapsible metal detector... It's odd, but potentially useful. I stash it in my bag, wondering when or why I even bought this.
events.hall2: Her room remains frozen—the same unmade bed, the same forgotten backpack. No clues about where she's gone.
events.hatch: A square hatch of wood graces the ceiling. How'd I forget about the attic? The pull-down ladder's been broken since childhood. Getting up there won't be easy.
events.street: I peer out my front window. A shadow by the telephone pole stands too tall, too still. My DVR security camera system would probably show grainy evidence, if I could get online to check it... but I haven't had internet for months.
events.attic: I place down the stepladder and use it to boost myself to the attic hatch, pulling myself up and through. I'm not sure how long it's been since I've been in here. Forever ago.
events.get-robe: The drawer reveals a blood-red robe with gold trim, nestled between mothballs. Why did Grandpa own this ceremonial-looking thing? The fabric smells of camphor and something earthier, but it might prove useful.
events.windowgaze: The window's grime distorts the world like a funhouse mirror. Vines slither through cracks, their stems unnaturally thick and glistening like oil-slicked flesh.
events.get-rope: Rope coils in heaps—some strands knotted into crude symbols. A few twitch when the wind rattles the pane. I gather them quickly, my skin prickling as the knots brush my palms.
events.nopass: The turnstile light blares red. My transit pass is still at home.
events.transit: The turnstile clicks open like a tongue. The station hums with bored commuters. A child's laugh is drowned out by crackling static from the speakers. 'Next train: Beach Line. Last departure today.' The clerk nods—like he's seen this play out before.
events.library:
The air stinks of ozone and rotting paper. The librarian's fingers tap like a metronome.

'Card?' she drones, nasally.

When I shake my head, she slides a signup form across the desk. A few minutes later, I have a new card in hand.

'Terminal three. One hour.'

Her tone suggests books aren't why people come here anymore.
events.library2: The monitor glows sickly. Social media? Blocked. News? Blocked. But local archives load: weather news, tide charts, arrest reports, notices about missing pets near the shore. The clock above the terminal ticks louder than it should.
events.left-library:
Fluorescents buzz weakly like dying flies as I step outside.

Across the square, a gargoyle on the library's facade watches me a beat too long. Its stone eyes seem to track my movement.
events.stacks:
Looking through old microfiche newspapers isn't my idea of fun, but what else can I do? I scan quickly for headlines about disappearances in town.

Here's one. Apparently the '86 chemical spill was a cover-up for cult activity, and hostages were rescued. A faded photo shows the sheriff padlocking that blue shack on the beach.

Somehow scribbled in the margin: '6-20-25, high tide on the solstice.' The numbers itch at my brain. Is it a date?
events.stacks2:
I go over what I've found. In old microfiche articles, there are headlines about local disappearances.

In '86, a cult called 'The Tide' was found responsible for numerous abductions. Faded photos relate the shack on the beach to this cult.

There are also numbers scrawled in the margins that seem important somehow: '6-20-25'.
events.detective2:
The detective's desk is a graveyard of files.

The detective himself, gone. But I'm here by invite. I get myself a coffee.
events.police-computer: The password screen shows his wallpaper—the detective and a woman holding up their wedding rings. He's actually smiling in the photo. The date in the corner is from three weeks ago.
events.evidence: A red vinyl chair stands out against the drab walls. Case labels whisper: 'Missing. Arson. Cult Activity?' Box #17 rustles faintly—like fingernails on cardboard. I step back.
events.paperwork: A detailed site-plan reveals a network of tunnels beneath the island mansion. The annotations suggest easy access if I approach from the north side. Someone drew a red circle around the property.
events.window: I tilt the blinds open further. Through wire-reinforced glass, the precinct buzzes with muted activity. I notice the assistant watching me, and I close the shutters again.
events.beach:
The shack shouldn't still be standing. Its blue planks look freshly painted despite decades of salt wind. The padlock gleams like new.

A weathered notice flaps:
'NO TRESPASSING BY ORDER OF THE SHERIFF'S OFFICE'

The rest is worn into illegibility.
events.dagger: The metal detector shrieks after I wave it around here a few times. Buried under a foot of sand: a ritual knife with a serrated edge. I nearly slice my finger digging it up.
events.sand: Hot grit slips through my fingers. Each handful feels heavier than it should. There's probably nothing here. Probably.
events.sky: The clouds hang like damp gauze—translucent and stubborn. They don’t move so much as peel, slow and grudging, as if the sky can’t decide whether to heal or scar. The sun bleeds through in patches, hot and uneven, like a fever pressing against glass.
events.shack: The blue shack from the articles. My only real lead. The rusty old padlock stares back, daring me to try its combination.
events.door: Heavy-duty combination lock. The dials turn stiffly but aren't frozen. Someone's been here recently enough to keep it from rusting shut.
events.dog: A massive dog blocks the path—muscle and matted fur. Its growl vibrates in my chest. Every childhood fear of dark basements and bad dogs surges up. Run. Now.
events.pet-dog:
Good doggo! The beast's tail wags as I scratch behind its ears. A wet tongue drags across my wrist.

[Sanity Restored!]
events.shack1: This is the same rusty old padlock I've seen in the photos. I try the numbers I saw earlier, 6-20-25, and the lock resists a moment before yielding. The door groans on its rusty hinges. The mildew smell hits first, then the sheer size of the interior. The building feels different now, as if this stopped being a shack the moment I crossed the threshold.
events.shack2: The lock explodes and metal flies. My hands still shaking from the vibration of the shot, I push against the door and it groans on its rusty hinges. The mildew smell hits first, then the sheer size of the interior. The building feels different now, as if this stopped being a shack the moment I crossed the threshold.
events.shack3: Tide charts cover the walls, their symbols playing tricks on my eyes. The floorboards warp unnaturally into stone. The air hums—not with wind, but voices. Chanting. Or maybe that's just the blood roaring in my ears.
events.get-ladder: I pick up the old metal stepladder from the corner, and carry it with me.
events.shack-desk:
The drawer reveals a map—recruitment targets circled in red ink. The hilltop mansion dominates the center, while outward arrows seem to indicate this is a sort of headquarters.

Recent coffee stains suggest this is still an active plan.
events.shack-drawers: Rope loops tangle in the drawer. Not a single length but dozens of pre-made hoops and nooses. They stack neatly despite their apparent grim purpose.
events.shack-empty: The drawers are mysteriously empty. Not counting the cobwebs...
events.mansion: A robed figure materializes from the shadows, pressing a flyer into my palm. His fingers stretch too long, his nails ridged with old blood. 'The Tide doesn't need you yet,' he rasps. Behind him, the mansion's windows pulse—not with light, but with movement.
events.cultist: The robed figure looms closer. My skin crawls with the certainty that his hood shadows no human face. Time to go.
events.cultist-scared: The robed figure looms closer. I wave my new gun in his face and he scampers off back into the mansion...
events.balcony: The balcony hangs just beyond reach. No matter how I jump, my fingers scrape empty air.
events.tunnels: I spend what feels like hours stumbling through lightless passages. My hands brush damp stone until finally—a door. The wood thrums under my touch.
events.has-rope: The rope snakes around the balcony post. One tug to test it, then I haul myself up, muscles screaming.
events.has-ladder: I set my ladder down against the balcony and easily climb over the rail. An empty room awaits me inside the mansion. I find my way to the altar...
events.need-key: The ornate lock stares back. No picking this—I'll need to find another way in.
events.knife: I knock, flashing the ritual blade. 'Lost my robe,' I lie. The cultists exchange glances before bowing me inside.
events.has-robe: The crimson robe earns me deep bows. They murmur titles—'High Priest'—as I stride past. The charade works better than expected.
events.mansion2: Funeral spices clot the air. Staircases multiply like spider legs. Each step crumbles at the edges. The whispers aren't coming from the walls—they're coming from between them.
events.rotunda: The dome fractures moonlight into living shapes. The seal on the floor pulses—not with light but pressure, its golden runes squirming when I blink. Blood shouldn't smell this sweet. The voices aren't echoes—they're in my jawbone.
events.altar: Names crawl across the altar's surface, each groove dark and damp. Mine sits half-finished. Touching the carvings leaves my fingers stinking of brine and burnt hair.
events.skylight: The stained glass warps the moon into a cataract eye. Below, the seal's runes aren't reflecting light—they're drinking it, pulsing in time with the distant tide.
events.leave: The door shuts with a groan. Wind carries something like my daughter's voice—or just vines scraping stone. The mansion's windows pulse twice as I walk away. Like a heartbeat. Like counting down.

insanity.ceiling-fan:
The fan’s blades carve slow circles into the air, a little louder than it should be. Click. Whir. Click. Like a metronome.

I’m reminded of my daughter’s favorite track — Victim, from that Dead Inside album she played too loud. 'Swinging dead in summer wind…' She’d mouth the words while braiding her hair, grinning like it was just some dumb lyric. But now the fan’s rhythm syncs with it. Click. Swinging. Whir. Dead.

'My parents will go crazy, slowly…'
I should get up. But the couch holds me like a hand.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.vines:
Just vines. Normal. Overgrown. Thin, fibrous tendrils creep down from the windowframe, curling like lazy fingers. They don’t move when I look at them. But when I turn away, in the corner of my vision, they twitch.

I reach up. The moment before my fingers touch one, the vine tightens. A shudder runs through the whole mass, like a muscle flexing.

Outside, the wind blows, and the vines go still. But now I can’t stop looking.
Every time I glance, they’ve gotten just a little closer to the floor.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.birds:
The birds hover in the wind. The ones on the sand tilt their heads in unison, black eyes locking onto me.

Then there’s the close one—close enough to touch. Its beak opens. Not a screech. A whisper.
“She’s right where you left her.”

I reach out. My fingers graze feathers. The gull collapses into a tangle of evaporating seaweed. The others take flight, their wings beating in unison.

Click. Whir. Click.
Just like the ceiling fan at home.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.ocean:
The waves don’t crash—they breathe. In. Out. Like the tide is a great, snoozing beast beneath the sand. The water isn’t blue anymore. It’s the color of a fading bruise. Purple. Yellow at the edges.

I count the waves. Their rhythm sings a song. Their shape seems square and digital. The ocean is holding its breath.

And then—a sound. Not a gull, not the wind. A voice, half-drowned, calling from the water on the horizon.

“You’re already too late.”
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.tracks:
The rails seem to hum even when no train is coming. A low, metallic vibration, like the tracks are singing to themselves. A tune without a melody. A warning without words.

The timetable board flickers—departure times melting into gibberish, then into symbols I almost recognize.
A shadow moves in the nearby train tunnel. Not a train. Something longer. Something that sways.

The rails go silent. The shadow is gone. But the taste of copper lingers on my tongue.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.ceiling:
The ceiling isn’t gone.
It’s just... farther now.

I crane my neck, expecting rafters, cobwebs, the underside of the roof—but there’s nothing. No. Not nothing. Worse.

The darkness pulses.
Like a throat swallowing.
Like something up there is breathing.

A drop of cold water lands on my cheek. I wipe it away. My fingers come back red.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.blood:
The blood isn’t dry. It squirms. Thin, glossy tendrils spider outward from the edges of each splash, creeping like liquid veins. The thicker pools ripple, as if stirred by an invisible finger.

I crouch, reaching—and the blood flinches away from me. It doesn't seem red anymore. It’s the same purple-black as the inside of my eyelids when I wake gasping at 3 AM.

I straighten up. The blood goes still. Now it’s just red blood again.

Probably.
[SANITY REDUCED]
insanity.magic:
The circle isn’t just glowing—it’s breathing.

The violet light pulses in time with some distant, depthless heartbeat. The symbols twist if I stare too long, their edges writhing like worms in wet soil.

I step closer. The light doesn’t cast shadows—it eats them, leaving only stark, fever-bright outlines. One rune flickers.

The light hums. It’s not a sound. It’s the vibration of a throat before it screams.
[SANITY REDUCED]

root.prompt: I still haven't found the combination, but then I recall that I may not need it:

options.tooltip: A bold strategy. Let's see if it works out.
Maybe we don't need violence for this.

fire.result:
I carefully aim the gun at the rusty padlock and exhale, slowly pulling the trigger...

Click.

Oh...

root.prompt: I've logged in on the library computer system. Select an action:

options.tooltip:
Request an interview about
my missing persons case.

Upload my evidence anonymously
for federal review.
Post flyer & images to rally townsfolk.
Scan through old articles and photos.
Log into the Home Camera online portal.

The screen flickers. A reflection?
My face looks... older.

email_police.result:
TO: rook@hfpd.gov ...

I send off my email to the Hatchetfield police department with everything I know so far. The detective replies almost immediately:

'Come in today. ASAP.
Make sure you aren't followed.
--Rook'

fbi_upload.result: A confirmation appears: 'Case #KT-118.29 opened. Agents dispatched.'

forum_post.result: I upload my pics and plea in a local forum and quickly see reactions. Local protestors are starting to gather even now.

search_results.result:
An article appears about a '1986 Beach Accident' but scanning the fine print shows this headline to be misleading.
Town members were abducted by cultists who left similar letters to the one I got. The article also shows info about a related shack on the north beach owned by this same cult.

view_cams.result: I log in to my DVR camera system's website. Last footage: 11:47 PM. Two shadows moving through her room. Two figures leave. She's been gone since last night!

close_computer.result: I sign out of the computer with plenty of time to spare on my account. The screen flickers and glitches, and returns to the login screen.

root.prompt:
The assistant's nails click against her keyboard.

'Missing persons? Detective's booked till Thursday.'

'Unless you have an appointment?'

My hesitation answers for me.

'Thought so.'

I just know I can't wait that long. She offers me a card with the detective's email address on it.

options.tooltip: I guess I need an appointment...

root.prompt:
The assistant sips her coffee.

'Missing persons? Detective's booked till Thursday.'

'Unless you have an appointment?'

options.tooltip: I do, in fact, have an appointment...
Not much else to do here...

root.prompt:
The assistant eyes me wearily.

“Detective Rook says you've been deputized.” She sighs. “Look, I’m sorry about your kid. But if you start waving a gun around, I [i][b]will[/b][/i] tase you.”
root.prompt2:
The assistant eyes me wearily.

“So, you've been deputized...” She leans in, lowering her voice. “That’s cop-speak for 'we have no leads'.”

options.tooltip: Revisit Rook's Office...
Sneak into the evidence room...
Not much else to do here...

root.prompt:
The detective's desk is a graveyard of files.

His left hand bears the ghost of a wedding ring—pale skin where perhaps gold recently rested. A photo slips from a folder: a dark-haired woman, smiling. Standing with him. Well, him from before.

He snatches it back before I can look too close.

“About your daughter. Where’d you last see her?”

options.tooltip: Honest. Truthful. Why wouldn't I be? She's my daughter!

be_open.result: I tell the detective everything I know. We played Scrabble until 9, said goodnight—she’s too old for bedtime stories. I ramble about the strange note, the argument we had over the boardgame, the sets of footprints in the sand outside my house.

detective_response.result:
He leans back, jaw tight. “You’re the fifth parent this month,” he mutters, voice sandpapered by cigarettes and something darker. “Funny how it’s always the same patterns.” The fan creaks overhead.

He steels himself. “There’s a shack on the beach down by the north shore — cult’s been using it...”

detective_response2.result: “And in addition to the shack, they've got a clifftop mansion on a island to the west. Both seemingly empty at high tide. I'd take you there myself, but it gets… unwelcoming after dark.”

offer_help.prompt:
He sighs, stands up, and shows me around the station.
“Look, you want in—come by anytime. Here. I’m deputizing you as an Auxiliary Officer. That means you’ve got the access, and the responsibility—but none of the arrest powers. You're not here to play cowboy. You’re here to assist, observe, and stay out of the way unless called upon. Understood?
Station’s open to you now. You’ll have free reign. Hell, I find the place comforting. Just—be careful out there.”

options.tooltip: I appreciate the reprieve.

end.result: I nod. For the first time since the note arrived, I feel a sliver of hope. The detective’s office feels less like an interrogation room and more like an ally’s living room.

root.prompt: She sits in shadows, arms crossed, uncertainty in her eyes.

options.tooltip: Reach out gently.
Plead my case.

rescue.result: Her hand trembles in mine. The cell door swings open. “Alright, let’s get out of here together.”

cult_master.prompt: I pause at the threshold of the sigil‑lit chamber. She watches me, calm as the tide. “I came here on my own,” she says. “Had a friend pick me up. I... I know what this place is. A new beginning. If not me, they'll find someone else. Either way, this world ends. But...” tears well up in her eyes. “You can stop it. The gods will sleep, if you only...”

options.text: If this is what you want
options.tooltip: Step back and let her choose.
Offer myself instead.

run.result:
She steps forward, voice trembling steel: “If you leave, I’ll have to do it myself. The eternal ones won’t wait.”

My heart breaks. “You don’t have to—”

She presses a hand to my chest. “Go. A new world awaits us both.”

I slip into the night. Behind me, her silhouette holds the dagger steady.

sacrifice.result:
I step into the circle, heart steady. “Take me instead,” I whisper. “Let them sleep.”

She nods, eyes bright. “This will stave off the end—give dawn one more chance.”

She lays her hand on mine, guiding the blade’s hilt. “Thank you. I’ll carry you in every sunrise.”

root.prompt: I rush into the dim cell where my daughter sits on a cold stone bench. She looks up—eyes red, arms crossed.

options.text: I’m so sorry I took so long
options.tooltip: Apologize and explain.
Insist she leave immediately.

apology.result: Her lip trembles. “You promised we’d finish Scrabble. You left me alone. I was scared.” She pulls the torn tile from her pocket. “I kept this safe. But it’s not enough.”

ask_fight.prompt: She glares. “Don’t change the subject. Last night you chose work over me.”

options.tooltip: Explain my duty.
Push to leave now.

protecting.result: She softens briefly. “Protecting? I found this note…” She shows the cult’s symbol carved in wood. “They said you’d come back for me. But what if they want you?”

insist.result: She stands, but shakes her head. “No. I don’t trust you. Not yet.”

reveal_cult.result: Her eyes go distant. “They chose me. I… I’m one of them now.” Her voice echoes strangely. “You should join me—or be next.”

daughter_decides.prompt: She steps away from the bars. Will she come with me, or stay as the cult’s heir?

options.tooltip: Reach out emotionally.
Give her space.

rescue_attempt.result: She hesitates, then squeezes my hand. The cell door clanks open. “Fine,” she whispers. “But if you fail…”

end_alone.result: She watches me go, tears glistening. The door stays shut. I walk away with a broken heart—and the chilling knowledge she leads the cult.

end_escape.result: Together we slip into the night. Behind us, the cult’s chanting fades—and we know they’ll come for both of us.

root.prompt: The drawer squeaks as I pull it open, revealing a small megaphone.

options.tooltip: This could potentially be useful.
Too risky. Let's leave it where it is.

take_megaphone.result: A quick glance toward the door, and into the bag it goes.

leave_megaphone.result: I carefully close the drawer again.

root.prompt: Rifling through paperwork, my fingers brush cold metal. A key marked 'Evidence' hidden beneath incident reports.

options.tooltip: This will probably get me into the evidence room...
Too risky. Let's leave it where it is.

leave_key.result: I put the papers back on top of the key, where they belong.

root.prompt: Maybe I shouldn't be digging through drawers, looting through evidence bags, but I don't know what might come in handy.

options.tooltip: Better to have it and not need it...
No way. Is this a felony?

take_gun.result: The revolver's grip sticks—sweat or old blood? Six chambers. One empty. The serial number's been filed away. I conceal the weapon on my person.

leave_gun.result: I carefully close the evidence drawer, leaving the chain of evidence intact.

endings.sanity:
Reality fractures into static—
a television left screaming in an empty room.

I blink up at a fluorescent sun, its sterile light peeling back the delusion: no missing daughter, no tide cult, just these four stained walls.
The horror isn’t that it wasn’t real. The horror is that I clawed my way back anyway.

The attic hatch still yawns above me. The abduction letter still whispers. Sanity is the cruelest prison. I close my eyes. Let the tide pull me under again.
endings.left:
I walk away down the salt‑slick road—
a lone siren wailing in the distance.

Her silhouette lingers in memory’s corner: 
refusing my hand, choosing shadows over safety.

The ocean’s whisper follows me:
a promise broken, a heart left behind.

Some doors never close; some echoes never fade.

When the eternal nightmares descend, I am not among the first to be taken...
endings.sacrifice:
Darkness blooms behind her smile—
a crown of tide‑etched bone.

She steps through the cell bars,
pulling me into the cult’s embrace.

My final breath tastes of brine and regret.

Her laughter drifts back to me,
calling me deeper into the endless tide.
endings.rescue:
We slip beyond the cult’s reach—
a pair of footprints side by side.

Her hand in mine feels warm and real,
a promise kept beneath a rising moon.

Behind us, the mansion lies silent.

Ahead, the night hums with fresh possibility.
endings.100: I linger in shadows, trading loyalty for time. She is extracted with surgical precision. The others remain unaware until long after I’m gone.
endings.101: I’m the whisper in the wires. The building catches fire from within. She meets me at the rendezvous, wrapped in smoke and silence.
endings.102: They call it an inside job. I leave no fingerprints. She thinks I’m a hero. I don’t correct her.
endings.110: I offer no allegiance, only calculated mercy. She is my only anchor. The cult is wounded but not destroyed.
endings.111: They ask what side I were on. I answer with a name: hers. In the end, that’s all that mattered.
endings.112: Her footsteps echo behind me. I didn’t stop them, not really. But I did enough. I hope that’s true.
endings.120: I stand in the spotlight, ash coating my shoulders. She walks beside me, stunned but alive. The reporters ask who I am. I lie.
endings.121: I turned the world’s attention on them. The cult breaks, screaming. She clings to me as the cameras flash.
endings.122: The flood begins with a smile. Mine. Her hand slips into mine like it was always meant to. The crowd parts for us both.
endings.200: I silence the guards and whisper old rites. The ritual proceeds. She walks willingly—eyes glazed, heart emptied.
endings.201: I hide in plain sight, rising through their ranks. The ritual goes smoothly. She thanks me. I nod.
endings.202: I bow with the others as the tide swallows the moon. She is reborn in salt and shadow. I accept the crown.
endings.210: The doctrine is mine now. I rewrite it to include her. The others chant. She just watches me.
endings.211: I stand above the altar, preaching futures no one wants. The crowd applauds. She weeps, unseen.
endings.212: I offer her to The Tide. The storm begins. The crowd chants my name as the world begins to tremble.
endings.220: The sky splits. The water answers. We are both quickly consumed—and satisfied.
endings.221: She laughs beside me, radiant and awful. Together, we welcome the end.
endings.222: The old gods rise, and she rises with them. I kneel. It is done.
endings.000: I vanish beneath the fog, unheard and unseen. Her small hand grips mine tightly. The Tide never even knew I was there.
endings.001: I ghost through the facility, rescuing her while the ritual crumbles behind me. No one believes what I saw. I disappear before anyone can ask.
endings.002: The sirens never sound. The cult falls, but so does something inside me. I walk out with her, white-eyed and trembling, the salt still clinging to her skin.
endings.010: I bend with the current but never break. She survives. We are both changed, but the world stays dry—for now.
endings.011: Through whispered warnings and double lives, I lead her out. The cult fractures in my wake. I fade back into the city like a rumor.
endings.012: Cameras catch my face. News anchors say my name. But she’s safe, and that’s enough. The rest is noise.
endings.020: I speak their language, then rewrite it. The cult thinks I'm one of their own—until it’s too late. I walk free, carrying only her.
endings.021: I shout above the waves, revealing everything. The building collapses. In the dust and panic, only I walk out with the girl.
endings.022: The sky opens, and the ritual completes. She is returned to me—not rescued, but transformed. I embrace her anyway. She smiles with too many teeth.
